citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
There is a golden retriever, 2yr old, M, (Clifford, 2558) that has a wound or growth approximately 2in x .5 inches long on
the inside lower left lip. The area is swollen and pink. The growth had not been observed in the past three weeks since
the last heartworm treatment, resulting in no veterinary diagnosis or direction at the time of the inspection. The dog was in
good condition and did not appear to be in any discomfort, however the growth/injury needs to be seen by a veterinarian.
The lack of timely veterinary care can cause a treatable condition to become chorinc and/or cause unnecessary dicomfort
to the regulated animal.
A veterinarian must be contacted for proper diagnosis and treatment.
The licensee took the dog to the attending veterinarian after the exit interview and is receiving proper treatment.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by March 19, 2024-60 days counted from 1st RL Inspection
or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule
your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
There is a golden retriever, 2yr old, M, (Clifford, 2558) that has a wound or growth approximately 2in x .5 inches long on 
the inside lower left lip. The area is swollen and pink. The growth had not been observed in the past three weeks since 
the last heartworm treatment, resulting in no veterinary diagnosis or direction at the time of the inspection. The dog was in 
good condition and did not appear to be in any discomfort, however the growth/injury needs to be seen by a veterinarian. 
 
The lack of timely veterinary care can cause a treatable condition to become chorinc and/or cause unnecessary dicomfort 
to the regulated animal. 
 
A veterinarian must be contacted for proper diagnosis and treatment.  
 
The licensee took the dog to the attending veterinarian after the exit interview and is receiving proper treatment. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by March 19, 2024-60 days counted from 1st RL Inspection 
or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule 
your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
